title: The world in brief
content: Catch up on global daily news Dive into compelling long reads Tune into engaging conversations Watch engaging short films Gain insights from experts Curated news, direct to your inbox Unlimited digital access to all reporting, podcasts, newsletters and events Catch up quickly on the global stories that matter Updated 7 hours ago Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said he is “fully committed” to talks with America in Saudi Arabia next week on ending the war. Earlier, he urged allies to tighten sanctions on Russia after strikes killed at least 14 people and wounded 37, officials said. Missiles hit homes in Dobropillia, a town in the east, killing 11, while three more died in Kharkiv, in the north. Iran’s Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said he would not negotiate under “bullying”. His comments follow Donald Trump’s letter proposing the talks. Mr Khamenei accused America of imposing new demands on Iran’s missile programme. During his first term America’s president abandoned a nuclear pact with Iran, which he said was too generous, but failed to secure a stricter agreement. title: Listen to Podcasts+
content:
Engaging conversations about global issues, business, China, American politics, technology and more. Get started with Economist Podcasts+. Global news | DAILY Gain a fresh perspective on the events and trends shaping your world with our daily podcast. China | WEEKLY Explore the stories and issues at the heart of China with our correspondents. Business and finance | WEEKLY Make sense of the biggest stories in business, economics and the markets. US politics | WEEKLY Stay ahead on American politics with in-depth discussions from our correspondents. Science and technology | WEEKLY Learn about the latest innovations and discoveries in science and technology. Global news | DAILY Enjoy a selection of articles read aloud from this week's issue of The Economist. Global news | DAILY Understand what's on the global agenda with this daily news briefing. Business | SERIES Uncover a predatory, multi-billion-dollar industry emerging from the shadows. US politics | SERIES Discover how the generation born in the era of the bomb blew up American politics. India | SERIES Find out how the world's most successful elected leader rose to power and how he is remaking India. Business | SERIES Learn how to be a better manager from CEOs who got to the top and experts who've studied them. China | SERIES Uncover the real story of China's leader and his rise to the top in this eight-episode series. Russia | SERIES Understand why the war in Ukraine began, how it might end and what the future holds for Russia. Science and technology | SERIES Join us to explore the people and stories behind game-changing ideas and innovations. Future | SERIES Catch a glimpse of the future as we examine an assortment of challenges facing the world. Future | SERIES Go behind the scenes of the future and meet the people who are building tomorrow's world. Covid | ARCHIVED Analysis of the science, data and politics behind the covid-19 jab as it happened. Science and technology | ARCHIVED A clear-eyed look at the technologies, the adaptation and the politics needed to address extreme climate change. Global news | ARCHIVED One question posed to a high-profile newsmaker, followed up with lively debate. title: War in the Middle East
content: Catch up on global daily news Dive into compelling long reads Tune into engaging conversations Watch engaging short films Gain insights from experts Curated news, direct to your inbox Unlimited digital access to all reporting, podcasts, newsletters and events All of our coverage in one place It remains present inside Syria, Lebanon, Gaza and the West Bank They both want to avoid a ceasefire collapse, for a few more weeks  Donald Trump’s chances of a grand bargain in the Middle East are shrinking But it will not be able to ignore the armed group entirely There is no plausible civilian use for the enhanced uranium Iran is producing People on both sides of the border are returning to devastated homes Joe Biden makes a last push to bring peace to the Middle East The Trump White House may bomb and penalise the regime into a deal  As he fights charges of corruption, his country’s democracy may suffer The Israeli prime minister stamps his authority on his government Who wins will shape Israel’s approach to its three wars Hawks and doves, religious and secular, right and left—all the old cleavages are resurfacing Is his call to evict Palestinians from the “hell hole” an imperial fantasy or a negotiating ploy? And he should see the region as more than a source of instability and arms deals Donald Trump provided the X factor by putting heat on Binyamin Netanyahu, who insists the war isn’t over yet Will Israel and Donald Trump use the threat of annexation to secure a new grand bargain? Why the conventional wisdom about decapitating Hamas and Hizbullah might be wrong They are 2km inside the country, but prepared to go farther A visual guide to the escalating conflict Binyamin Netanyahu says the presence of Israeli troops is crucial. His generals disagree Look beyond the latest bravado and brutality and it is bitterly split Hamas and the Israeli far right both want to destabilise the West Bank Will his successor embrace more violence or compromise? Will his death moderate or aggravate its bloody ethos?  Middle East & Africa It remains present inside Syria, Lebanon, Gaza and the West Bank  Middle East & Africa They both want to avoid a ceasefire collapse, for a few more weeks   Middle East & Africa But it will not be able to ignore the armed group entirely  Middle East & Africa The arrest of a prominent bookseller in Jerusalem bodes ill for freedom of expression  Middle East & Africa Donald Trump’s chances of a grand bargain in the Middle East are shrinking  Leaders As well as some hard truths  Middle East & Africa Is his call to evict Palestinians from the “hell hole” an imperial fantasy or a negotiating ploy?  Graphic detail Evidence from more than 2,000 truces reveals their effectiveness     Middle East & Africa Look beyond the latest bravado and brutality and it is bitterly split  Middle East & Africa Hamas and the Israeli far right both want to destabilise the West Bank  Middle East & Africa But the ceasefire is not yet the end of the war  Leaders Their Red Sea protection racket is a disturbing glimpse into an anarchic world To enhance your experience and ensure our website runs smoothly, we use cookies and similar technologies. title: Ukraine at war
content: Catch up on global daily news Dive into compelling long reads Tune into engaging conversations Watch engaging short films Gain insights from experts Curated news, direct to your inbox Unlimited digital access to all reporting, podcasts, newsletters and events All of our coverage of the war in one place And the grim choice facing Volodymyr Zelensky Some fear a hero is in danger of becoming a tragic figure By trying to stop the rift, Europe may hasten it Investing in Ukraine’s own weapons industry will be the best bet Where an American American cut-off of military aid will hurt most  A summit in London is stalked by the fear America will walk away A proposed economic deal would be punitive. Saying “no” could be worse  America’s president calls Ukraine’s president “a dictator”  At an emergency meeting in Paris there are splits on sending troops to Ukraine  Europe has been left scrambling after an attack on the partnership that kept the peace for nearly 80 years There is no more fog of war Drone operators and jammers are in a high-tech arms race An ominous defeat in the eastern town of Velyka Novosilka And learning a lot about sanctions-busting A heavy-handed mobilisation campaign is unable to fill gaps in the front lines Residents of Kherson are dodging murderous drones Atomic power may not solve the country’s energy woes The Trump administration should remember Vladimir Putin’s dark vision In a strong economy, price pressure can endure for a long time The Kremlin blames a campaign of subversion and psychological warfare   Despite advances on the battlefield, pressure is growing Its mercenary model is still effective in Africa’s most fragile places  Europe By trying to stop the rift, Europe may hasten it  Europe Investing in Ukraine’s own weapons industry will be the best bet  Leaders And the grim choice facing Volodymyr Zelensky  Europe Where an American American cut-off of military aid will hurt most   Europe A summit in London is stalked by the fear America will walk away  Leaders As they meet in London, Vladimir Putin will sense weakness  Europe Some fear a hero is in danger of becoming a tragic figure  Europe J.D. title: The World Ahead 2025
content: Catch up on global daily news Dive into compelling long reads Tune into engaging conversations Watch engaging short films Gain insights from experts Curated news, direct to your inbox Unlimited digital access to all reporting, podcasts, newsletters and events Future-gazing analysis, predictions and speculation The World Ahead The World Ahead 2025 A letter from the editor of The World Ahead The World Ahead The world in 2025 Watch the interplay between Donald Trump, technology and radical uncertainty The World Ahead United States in 2025 The MAGA scale of policy plausibility provides a handy five-part guide The World Ahead European security in 2025  But none of its major governments seems ready to face the future The World Ahead Geopolitics in 2025 The deterrence deficit will become starkly visible in the coming year The World Ahead Economics in 2025 His explosive plan for tariffs will damage world trade, but he will struggle to implement it in full The World Ahead Immigration in 2025 America will not be the only country trying to curb migration in 2025 Imposing a maximum-age limit on elected politicians may seem sensible, but would be illiberal The World Ahead The year ahead Our selection of events taking place around the world The World Ahead Superforecasters in 2025 The experts at Good Judgment weigh in on the coming year The World Ahead Backbenchers and backbiting But it can afford to, because the Conservatives will be fighting everyone else The World Ahead Britain in 2025 Smaller parties are thriving The World Ahead Growing pains Conditions for economic growth are favourable, but results are uncertain The World Ahead Coastally awesome But you may need to bring your wellies The World Ahead This mortal coil A shift has begun to happen among politicians The World Ahead Europe’s perilous choice Go it alone on defence, stick with America or try to muddle through? The World Ahead Ukraine’s gloomy end-game What might a possible deal look like?  The World Ahead A thousand cuts It will affect politics and the war in Ukraine, too   The World Ahead Balancing act France looks increasingly unstable The World Ahead Poles apart It could end the current uneasy cohabitation with a hard-right president The World Ahead Exit Scholz, enter Merz Getting the economy going will be the priority The World Ahead The sequel is usually worse The new president has control of Congress. What will his priorities be when he assumes office? The World Ahead United States in 2025  The way forward is far from clear The World Ahead Trump’s rich inheritance Politics will not spoil it—but Donald Trump’s agenda presents some serious risks The World Ahead United States in 2025 In his contempt for allies, the new president will probably add to the chaos The World Ahead Green to brown Does this spell the end for America’s green-energy push? The World Ahead Over here In some ways he will succeed The professor of history and grand strategy at the US Naval War College says history offers valuable lessons The World Ahead Handle with care The topics he cares about—immigration, trade and drugs—put the region in the crosshairs The World Ahead Crossing continents The struggle over migration in Latin America will deepen in 2025 The World Ahead Crime and hard punishment Two elections in 2025 could show growing support for tougher security policies The World Ahead The Americas in 2025 But it is still just a start  The World Ahead Time’s up A pugnacious Conservative could win the 2025 election The World Ahead By Invitation: The Americas in 2025 Governing with economic prudence has revived growth, says Javier Milei, president of Argentina The World Ahead By the people, for the people There are some worrying signs The World Ahead Investing in India’s future The government’s reliance on public investment is probably not sustainable The World Ahead Building it And not before time  The World Ahead Japan’s 2025 problem Bold reforms and greater honesty are needed The World Ahead Unpopularity contest A general election will pit two unpopular leaders against each other The World Ahead Echoes of 1949 Its army has never been hit this hard The World Ahead Pacific tensions But it will also create opportunities for the Communist Party The World Ahead Lower-tier cities Those on the second and third tiers are thriving The World Ahead Reefs and beefs South-East Asian nations are pushing back against China The World Ahead Business challenges They face challenges both domestic and foreign in 2025 The World Ahead Post-solar power It aims to lead the way on hydrogen, carbon capture and other technologies The World Ahead A silver-haired lining? The “silver economy” could be a lucrative growth area in 2025 The World Ahead Israel’s wars Ali Khamenei, Binyamin Netanyahu and Donald Trump will determine whether the conflict continues The World Ahead Israeli politics He wants to avoid a reckoning The World Ahead Iran and America Perhaps an elusive handshake awaits The World Ahead Gulf partnerships It is proving a tricky balancing act The World Ahead The young and restless If there are not enough jobs, the consequences could be serious The World Ahead Sudan sinks The outside world cares less about it than about Gaza and Ukraine The shift presents opportunities but stokes new tensions  Several fast-growing economies show that not everyone is having a lost decade  The World Ahead Diplomacy in 2025 Donald Trump must decide how to compete in a new arms race The World Ahead Alliances in 2025 Each hot issue brings a new global alliance The World Ahead Climate change in 2025 It all depends on the latest figures from China, the world’s largest emitter The World Ahead Politics in 2025 Countries are ageing with them  The World Ahead Technology in 2025 Prepare for a worldwide wrangle over copyright, deepfakes and more The World Ahead Travel in 2025 Travel trends will return to more normal levels Global conflict is rising, but peacemaking is still vital, argues the president of International Crisis Group The World Ahead The World Ahead 2025 A global round-up from The Economist Intelligence Unit The World Ahead Wild cards To navigate the future, it can help to anticipate the unlikely The World Ahead Energy’s next big thing From giant batteries to compressed gas, energy storage is booming The World Ahead The limits of AI Prepare for superchips, supercomputers—and supersize headaches The World Ahead Home-made chips Expect more export bans, a supply glut and creative sanctions-dodging The World Ahead Business in 2025 American tariffs are helping to drive their expansion overseas The World Ahead East meets West They will also focus less on Western markets The World Ahead Xi’s electric With their surprising and innovative features, they are streets ahead Genuine diversity will still be welcome, radical ideology less so Time to look beyond language models, argues the Stanford professor and “godmother of AI” The World Ahead Down to earth The global economy has had a series of shocks, including the pandemic, an inflation spike and the invasion of Ukraine. As the dust settles, what has changed? The World Ahead Vitamin boost The price of oranges, coffee and uranium will stay high The World Ahead Beyond the hype Everyone calm down a little The World Ahead A new Asian pecking order Will that cause an “India shock” for the world economy? The World Ahead Flotation tanks Share prices are close to all-time highs, but private firms do not seem tempted The World Ahead Finance in 2025  Having hit new highs in 2024, markets could be about to get rocky again The World Ahead Making pharma go faster Software-inspired medicines are getting closer to prime time The World Ahead A new hope mRNA technology could once again be a game-changer The World Ahead Science & technology in 2025 The action is shifting from the public to the private sector The World Ahead Sensitivity about climate The coming year will be a big one for the advance of climate science The World Ahead Watch this space Humans may fly around the Moon, and robots will explore new frontiers The World Ahead By Invitation: Science & technology in 2025 Large-scale production of synthetic fuel is now feasible, argues the founder of Terraform Industries The World Ahead From Marvel to Mario The built-in audience is already huge  The World Ahead An enduring romance The anniversary of her birth will be widely commemorated The World Ahead Homeward bound? Britain could end up losing its marbles The World Ahead Touching down The National Football League will play more games abroad in 2025 than ever before The World Ahead Pay more, watch less TV’s golden era comes to an end The World Ahead Long story short Entertaining and innovative, micro-dramas are flourishing both at home and abroad in 2025 The World Ahead Obituary in 2025 First observed by Galileo, this occurs twice every 29 years To enhance your experience and ensure our website runs smoothly, we use cookies and similar technologies.
